text.p: Following are some of the major events to have occurred on July 5 in history:
1791 - George Hammond was appointed as Britain's first ambassador to the United States.
1810 - P.T. Barnum, U.S. showman, born; together with James Bailey, he founded the Barnum and Bailey Circus.
1811 - Venezuela declared independence from Spain.
1826 - Sir Thomas Stamford Raffles, British East Indian administrator and founder of Singapore in 1819, died.
1830 - France began an invasion of Algeria and took Algiers.
1853 - Cecil Rhodes, British colonial administrator in whose honour Rhodesia was named, born.
1865 - William Booth founded the Christian Mission, later renamed the Salvation Army, in London.
1865 - The world's first speed limit, of two miles perhour, was imposed in Britain under the Locomotives and Highways Act.
1872 - Edouard Herriot, French statesman, radical socialist and prime minister, born. Imprisoned by the Germans in 1942, he was not released until Russian troops entered Berlin in 1945.
1879 - Dwight Davis, U.S. tennis player and politician, born; he founded the Davis Cup tennis competition and served under President Coolidge as secretary of war (1925-29).
1889 - Jean Cocteau, a major figure in French culture, born. A poet, film director, novelist and artist, he made the films "Orpheus" and "Beauty and the Beast"
1911 - Georges Pompidou, French statesman, prime minister and president of France (1969-74), born.
1932 - Antonio de Oliveira Salazar became premier of Portugal and drafted a new constitution that established the country as an authoritarian state.
1945 - U.S. General MacArthur announced the liberation of the whole of the Philippines.
1945 - John Curtin, prime minister of Australia during most of World War Two, died.
1948 - The National Health Service came into being in Britain.
1959 - Indonesian President Sukarno dissolved parliament and assumed dictatorial powers for himself.
1965 - Maria Callas gave her last stage performance, singing Tosca at London's Covent Garden.
1969 - The Rolling Stones gave a free concert in Hyde Park, London, in memory of Brian Jones, who had died two days before.
1969 - Thomas Mboya, Kenyan statesman, assassinated.
1975 - American Arthur Ashe beat countryman Jimmy Connors to become the first black tennis player to win the Wimbledon men's singles title.
1975 - Independence from Portugal was granted to the Republic of Cape Verde, with Aristides Pereira becoming the country's first president.
1977 - In Pakistan, General Mohammad Zia-ul-Haq overthrew the government of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto in a bloodless coup.
1980 - Bjorn Borg of Sweden won the Wimbledon men's singles title for the fifth consecutive year.
1989 - Former White House aide Oliver North was fined 150,000 dollars for his role in the Iran-Contra scandal that rocked the Reagan administration.
1991 - The Bank of England said the operations of Bank of Credit and Commerce International SA (BCCI) had been suspended immediately following allegations of massive fraud.
1994 - Yasser Arafat travelled to the West Bank after 27 years in exile, determined to turn the self-rule areas of Gaza and Jericho into a Palestinian state with its capital in East Jerusalem.
1994 - In Italy, a graft trial opened with two former prime ministers heading a list of accused reading like a "who's who" of the country's fallen mighty.
